headline: Memories of Berlin
teaser: I remember how cold it was...
content:
There are many things that lay forgotten, like herbal teabags you never get around to drinking, as so it is with memories.From one day to the next you never give them a thought and then something triggers them and they come back in full color. And so it was in January 2025 with the election if Donald Trump to a second term that politics got interesting again. Some pundit remarked that for the first time in years the American public had been given a real choice, between left and right. Like many a modern democracy the choice had been between Coke or Pepsi taking turns. Now it was socialism and censorship or capitalism and free speech.

This event coincided with the conviction of the mass murderer Axel Rudakubana, who had stabbed three small girls and killed them in Southport.

The knives were also out for Kier Starmer who had become wildly unpopular for his handling of the whole shooting match. The looney left and the racist right. My memory of the time I saw the left and right in closeup.

Sometime in the 80s, through a friend, I had wangled a trip to Berlin. This would have been few years prior to the fall of The Wall. There was still a smell of Len Dayton in the the air when I landed at Tegel airport. Bomb damage was still evident, and a large military presence loomed. Rudolf Hess was cooling his heels in Spandau prison, which was in a posh bit of Berlin.

To paint a little background to my story I need to explain how things were in Berlin at the time. First to say that the Russians had won the war, with Americans and British Empire joint second and the French taking up the rear, so to speak. Germany was divided into the Bundes Republic in the west and the DDR in the east. Berlin was in the east and was accessible though a road corridor or by air.

The allies shared the territory of Berlin which was split into four zones. American, British, Russian and French. No one could tell me why the French were there. Someone said they threatened to sulk if not and wanted to make it look like they had been in the war.

Berlin at the time was still under marshall law, although the Berlin police were still in business giving out traffic tickets and investigating disturbances among Germans, they had no power over the military , so nome Germans parked where they liked ( with reason) .

It was far easier to visit as a member of the armed forces and so I took King‚Äôs Shilling, signed the Official Secrets Act and was given a little ID card. No uniform was offered so I could pretend to be a spy, maybe. I I was allowed into the NAFFI where the food was pretty awful, but the tea was OK, and the bar convivial.

Being driven around West Berlin I was puzzled to see a large black car flying Soviet flags with important looking passengers. It was explained that this was a ‚Äúflag tour‚Äù where the soviets showed their right to drive around West Berlin. This has been part of the Potsdam Treaty I was told.

Come Saturday I joined a tour bus of new arrivals and set off for a look at East Berlin. I remember having to change some Deutschmarks in Ost marks at one for one, which was a swizz as Deutschmarks were worth much more. I got to see the Escapees Museum at checkpoint Charlie, where you good see cars, aircraft and other smuggler stuff. Also stories of those killed trying to escape the soviet paradise.

As I said, it was Saturday and West Berlin was in full shop, shop, shop, and busy. The East was like a tomb. Streets empty, buildings empty, bomb sites, and as West berlin had some post war real estate development, the East look well preserved from the pre war era. On the main drag, nothing. Then in the distance came the sound of an angry wasp which turned out to be a Trabant, a sort of Reliant Robbin, but no so reliable. This was a workers car that you had to wait years for. It came and went, then nothing. The occasional Russian Officer walked by in full uniform with a chest of medals. We spent our marks of a cup of undrinkable coffee and an inedible sausage.

There was a clothes shop, but it only sold gloves ( rabbit skin ). I didn‚Äôt check mut I hope they were of mixed left and right? A grubby supermarket had a large line outside, then a coach drew up. They said they were from Poland on a shopping trip. There contrast East and West, was impressive.

I stayed maybe a week or so, then got DE mobbed, and returned home. It would be a few years before the wall was to come down, but we all knew which way the human tide would flow.

headline: Why you can't tune a piano
teaser: In fact it's impossible, we just do our best
content:
#music

Well, first off I have to admit that I can‚Äôt tune a piano. Number one obstacle being that I don‚Äôt own a piano, nor do I know anyone who does who would be foolish enough to let me try. Nor do I have the tools to do it, like a tuning fork, ( always something new to buy üòâ ) or that Allen key with a tommy bar on the top, plus all the felt needed to replace any that‚Äôs missing, or the little wooden hammers, or the glue. All could be remedied by a quick tap on Amazon, and a short wait.

More importantly, I don‚Äôt have the know how, or the skill to tune a piano. When I was a lad, piano tuning was quite a thing, we were at the tail end of the piano revolution when the height of Victorian status was an upright in the parlor. ( snigger, cough, sorry ). You couldn‚Äôt find a piano tuner easy enough, unless you lived in the sticks, and our local man, just up the road was Mr. Wooten.

Now, Mr. Wooten was very old, and his wife not so much. I didn‚Äôt know much about him, except he was locally famous for something ( maybe he played back in the day ) before he went blind? Piano tuners were frequently blind people, or am I making that bit up? Anyway, thing was that Mrs. Wooten only had one hand. The other was a split hook that opened and closed, and it scared me, as she worked in the local shop and I had to go errands there.

Well, Mr. Wooten arrived with his bag of tricks and gave our old Joanna a good servicing .. so to speak, as he couldn‚Äôt give her a ‚Äúseeing to‚Äù , if you get my drift.

I watched him with interest, I remember. This was something you didn‚Äôt see every day. It seemed to take a long enough time, and I still have the distant memory, but to get back to the original question, the answer is that it‚Äôs impossible. To tune a piano.

‚ÄúWait , wait ,wait‚Äù, I hear you cry, how come people are paying good money to someone to do the impossible, which would be a paradox anyway. If it‚Äôs just a matter of hitting the right frequency then surely there‚Äôs an app for that nowadays. And true enough. Although hitting the right frequency is not the problem. It‚Äôs that ‚Äúyee canny change the laws of physics, Captain‚Äù, and this falls into the ‚Äústem subjects basket‚Äù.

I‚Äôll now do my best to explain. ( Or go look on Wikipedia for yourself ).

Imagine a piece of string, or catgut, or wire or whatever. If you stretch it like in a guitar, violin, or piano, and pluck it, bow it, or hit it with a mallet, it will make a sound. This has been know for a few years now. Scientists believe its due to vibration of the string and indeed, harmonic motion is a well plowed row.

Now it you take a sting half as long it will vibrate at a frequency twice as high. That‚Äôs know as a octave, for reasons which are quite ironic, as you‚Äôll see later.

Humans, ( and many pets ) find this a pleasing harmonic as the notes don‚Äôt beat on again the other. If two notes are ‚Äúout of tune‚Äù, it can sound quite awful and you can hear a ‚Äúbeat‚Äù depending on how they differ. That‚Äôs how Mr. Wooten would have found his first note, by striking a tuning fork and listening for the beats while tickling the Allen key to get the string to the right pitch. Armed with one correct note the octaves could be tuned with reference to that note, or by the fork. So far, so good.

Now let‚Äôs think about the circle of fifths. A perfect fifth from C gets you to G. And a perfect fifth sounds very nice, just tune away the beats and you get the perfect fifth. So now carry from G. The next up is D. G to D is a perfect fifth. D to A, and so on, A to E and so on and that will bring us back to Doe. Or should I say ‚ÄúDoh!:, because it doesn‚Äôt. It‚Äôs slightly out. So when you get back to C and test it against where you stated it‚Äôs not an exact number of octaves away.

The piano will have been tuned in ‚Äújust temperament‚Äù, and it should sound vey pleasing, except it will only play in the key of C. So if you don‚Äôt want more than one key signature, go for it. Problem comes when you play a duet with the person next door who has his or her instrument tuned in a different key.

In years back , like when people wore tall wigs, they would have a ‚Äúbox of viols‚Äù like little pianos tuned to different keys. Quite impractical. Someone, at some time, invented the piano, and with it ‚Äúequal tempering‚Äù, which was a big thing. Bach even wrote a bit of music about it. The modern era began. So, what is a ‚Äúwell tempered clavier‚Äù?

It‚Äôs a compromise , so that each note is a bit out making 12 equally spaced sounds, 11 of them a bit out. To get the frequency of the next note up, multiply the current note by the 12th root of 2 ( think about it ). I would have imagined Mr. Wooten would have used his skill and judgement to make the piano sound ‚Äúsweet‚Äù, and indeed there were guidelines as to how to achieve this avoiding the ‚Äúwolf frequencies‚Äù, so that there was even more of a compromise, the 12 keys would not be equally spaced, so that the ‚Äúcommon keys‚Äù might sound sweeter.

A guitar player has a similar dilemma. So you may see them twigling the machine head for their next song to ‚Äúdrop the fifth‚Äù a shade to make the country music sound better. ( I actually do like a lot of country music , which drops my music cred like a hot brick).

A violinist can laugh at them as the violin has no frets, and the player wobbles their left hand anyway. Brass instruments can be tuned, but valves give the piano problem, except the trombone, it has a slider.

Electronic music can ‚Äúdo anything‚Äù, as can the human voice, which is why a choir sounds so angelic.

Now I‚Äôve written enough, but there‚Äôs still a lot to say. Maybe in a future post. Give this a viddy, then go tune something.

content:
Try to Catch The Wind

#music

No, nothing to do with eating Brussel sprouts. I was provoked this morning by reading about upcoming developments in Coplot AI inside GitHub ( Microsoft ), which would seem a natural match. I made me think how far we have come in my memory, and speculate where we will go to next. A.I. has moved so quicky that to me, just as I start to grok it, it morphs into something else, like the hydra, but maybe in a good way.

My first program was written in Secondary school in Mr. Copley’s class. Mr. Copley was famous for his R.E. classes so it was a little strange that he should pop up in the maths department. I had already learned some things from the Open University TV about Boolean logic, analogue v digital, simple programing languages like Basic and Algol, but I was yet to get the baptism of running my first program.

The teacher give us the basic outline, and demonstrated how Fortran did its thing with some examples. Then we were told to get out our notebooks and write a simple program. Next lesson, we got some punch cards and a magnetic pencil and converted each symbol into three marks in every column. This was sent away somewhere and returned together with a printout of the code. I don’t remember a hand punch entering the loop anywhere. Long story short I eventually got the output from my program. For the record it was calculating various scenarios or the taps and baths problem. It worked!

There I left it, through 6th form nothing. University, nothing. Post Grad, back to Fortran, a bit of PDP assembler, and some interactive Basic. Never saw a graphic terminal till someone in a lab acquired a Commadore Pet. It played poker.

Eventually I got a job and became a Junior Programmer. 25 or so years in the industry, partly as a contractor, I was able see how it evolved from close up. The PC was a new thing, which I didn’t acquire from many years, but I saw technologies, languages, paradigms come and go. languages included, Cobol, Dibol, Fortran, C, C++,Basic and a few odd balls. I loved it. I would make sure to get my copy of Byte every month, got an AOL account. The days of buying a book, or a bit of software then emailing the author and expecting a reply.

Now for A.I. It seemed at first to be something I didn’t understand that people used to make funny photos and present them to you. It was quite a buzz, and the the rise of the chatbots whether the proverbial Mother or Grandmother is using Chat GPT on a regular basis, I think not.

The news today enthusing about what the beta versions of the GitHub, Copilot team could do left me a bit stunned.

Over to Grok.

GitHub is home to over 420 million repositories as of late 2024, hosting code written by more than 150 million users. These repositories contain an immense volume of code across countless programming languages, frameworks, and projects. While GitHub doesn‚Äôt publicly disclose the exact number of lines of code stored on its platform, we can make an educated guess based on available data and trends.

A single moderately sized repository might contain anywhere from a few thousand to tens of thousands of lines of code, while large projects‚Äîlike open-source frameworks or enterprise software‚Äîcan easily exceed millions of lines. For instance, the Linux kernel alone has over 30 million lines of code. If we conservatively assume an average of 10,000 lines per repository (accounting for both small scripts and larger projects), multiplying that by 420 million repositories gives us a rough estimate of 4.2 trillion lines of code on GitHub. This is likely an underestimate, as many repositories are far larger, and GitHub‚Äôs growth continues to accelerate.

Copilot, however, wasn‚Äôt trained on every single line of code in every GitHub repository. It was developed using a subset of publicly available code, filtered and processed by OpenAI to create its underlying model, Codex. This training data includes billions of lines of code from public GitHub repositories, though the exact figure isn‚Äôt disclosed. Research and industry reports suggest that large language models like Codex are trained on datasets containing tens to hundreds of billions of lines of code, drawn not just from GitHub but also from other public sources like Stack Overflow and open-source archives. Given GitHub‚Äôs dominance as the largest code hosting platform, it‚Äôs reasonable to estimate that Copilot‚Äôs training data includes at least 50 to 100 billion lines of code from GitHub alone.

Back to me. Seems that Copilot and GitHub could be used to maybe develop improved AI models, or at least improve the GitHub codebase in general. This is synergistic so this feels like a hockey stick moment in time. The singularity is near, or maybe it’s already here.

I'll leave you with a song.

headline: Eugenics
teaser: Go look it up
content:
No, it‚Äôs not about them

I don‚Äôt know what the prefix ‚Äúeu‚Äù means, but I think it might be greek. It seems to be used for something that‚Äôs good like ‚Äúeuphoria‚Äù, that‚Äôs good isn‚Äôt it? Well, no, not always. It‚Äôs a long story, but many years ago I ‚Äúsuffered‚Äù a bout of euphoria that would not go away. Well, it‚Äôs great at first, who wouldn‚Äôt enjoy that? But after a while it became a bit embarrassing, people saying ‚Äúwhat you smiling at?‚Äù. This only applied realy to people who had known the miserable old me as strangers just assumed I was a jolly good fellow.

A dentist told me he thought I may have a brain tumor!!! They used to be ‚Äúmister‚Äù then they became ‚Äúdoctor‚Äù and got big headed.

It had come overnight, with no ‚Äúby your leave‚Äù, and yes, it was pretty nice. But after a while it got tedious and also exhausting. It was like manic depression where people get mood swings but without the depression. I did try looking on the internet, but couldn‚Äôt find anything. ( btw I have had low cholesterol all my life, and tried to get info on that but all I got was advice on how to lower my cholesterol . Fat lot of use that ). But I digress. Rest assured after a few months I did manage to return to normal, but I still have low cholesterol.

Right. the ‚Äúeu‚Äù prefix is when they are trying to sell you on something good, like ‚Äúeuphoria‚Äù or ‚Äúeuthanasia‚Äù or ‚ÄúEuropean Union‚Äù ( I didn‚Äôt vote btw ). And ‚Äúeugenics‚Äù.

It‚Äôs a movement that promoted selective breeding of human beings. This was to get rid of some inherited diseases, or to improve the human race by only good looking people or really smart people could breed. I never understood all the details, but you can see how it may be a ‚Äúgood thing‚Äù. It was started by the greeks , but got really popular in the 1920‚Äôs. People like George Bernard Shaw and Adolphe Hitler. It was quite a respectable point of view until Hitler got involved then it was mostly thought of as a ‚Äúbad thing‚Äù.

It‚Äôs a fact, I think, that most modern farm animals are very different from the mark one version. Maybe the
prehistoric cow had tiny udders and thin milk. Roll on a few hundred generations an ‚ÄúVoil√†!‚Äù gold top milk. Skinny pigs become ‚ÄúDanishhhhhh‚Äù. And so on. The modern border collie was whipped up in just a few hundred years, now they are as smart as a pin.

Aldous Huxley wrote ‚ÄúBrave New World‚Äù, ( as did Billy Shakespeare ), about a dystopian future where people were put into different classes. Alpha, beta etc. I can see people in the bottom classes objecting to eugenics, who wants to be in the bottom class? Huxley also wrote ‚ÄúIsland‚Äù, which is about a Utopia, ( should be Eutopia shouldn‚Äôt it? ). And another thing, if two smart people get married and have a child the sprog is likely to be less intelligent than its parents. If two dullards do the same then the kid is smarter, thus increasing the average IQ of the race. Maybe that‚Äôs why eugenics never took off.

Anyway, I‚Äôve pretty much posted what I intended to. A bit of a first eh?

headline: Early to bed, early to rise
slug: It's Nice to get up in the Morning
teaser: As the old song has it, it's nice to get up in the morning. Sir Harry Lauder, had it right... until the last verse.
content:
It's nice to get up in the morning, and I'm an early bird by nature. I remember my father was an early riser, he would sip his tea and whistle while smoking a cigarette sitting on the kitchen step. ( but not all at once of course ). So habits are passed on, and I've always enjoyed my early rising, albeit that it seems to be an source of annoyance and irritability, incredulity, and even horror among most people.

It's true it's the early bird that catches the worm ( and the second mouse that gets the cheese ). To be sure while the lark is "up with the lark" I'm sure there's many an eagle that lies a snoozing in the nest waiting to get up and go hunting.

So, what are the advantages to getting up early? And why do I still do it? The advantages are legion, so I'll just name a cohort or two, ( thanks "Doctor In the House" ).

1. It's nice and quiet. I enjoy peace and quiet, helps me relax and plan the day ahead. Daily chores are easier with fewer folk around, less distraction. Also allows me to establish a morning routine.

2.Roads are empty, busses with fewer people, and the shop easier to negotiate early in the day.

3.The Sunrise. An amazing sight, many people go mosts of their lives without seeing it ( apparently ). The change from twilight as the birds begin to sing, the gradual light appear, the, if you know where to look you get to see the sky change color, the first few rays bent by gravity ( it seems ) , the flashlight on the clouds, then it suddenly erupts. A fantastic sight, and it's free and it happens every morning ( so far ). Think of all the effort the almighty has put into the sunrise, and you'r still snoozing in bed.

Now you have the whole day ahead of you? What will you do?

Now, the flip side is that unless you want to deprive yourself of sleep, you need to be "early to bed, early to rise", so rather than watching some stale old movie on TV you should be tired and ready for a good nights sleep. No tossing and turning, sleeping tablets, night caps, jus head to pillow, close eyes, relax, sweet dreams, and soon it's morning again. Miracle.

headline: A matter of scale
teaser: A gnats bollock
content:
Here I continue the epic story of the building of the crib. Almost all Mexican households have a crib just as the British have a Christmas tree, which is not to say the don‚Äôt have a Christmas tree as well. Part of the reason is to do with how Christmas is celebrated in Mexico.

On the whole, the two countries don‚Äôt differ much, but you would notice the difference if you were here.
To start with, the big day is the 24th, Christmas eve ( Noche Buena ). There is agreement that Christ was born on Christmas day in the morning, but they like to nip in quick and celebrate as soon as. This is where the crib comes into play, AKA the nacimiento. On the 24th most people like to be with family. The Christmas meal is on the 24th in the evening, when traditional foods are eaten, there a few drinks of beer or tequila. People will often attend mass at 7.00 pm or later as I guess there are repeat performances due to demand, then go on to the party later.

A few years ago I lived near to a large church of some fame and thought I should pop down and have a look, I was rather disappointed to find it was closed ( for Christmas ). I‚Äôm sure others were open, but I wasn‚Äôt that bothered. I filed that one away as ‚Äústrange but true‚Äù.

As midnight approaches families will gather, ‚Äúpeople wander in from outside courts‚Äù a la Wimbledon on finals day. By about 10 o‚Äôclock the nibbles are running out, and the food tends to appear. Best cutlery, cloth napkins etc. depending on the family.

The foods are as follows:

Bacalao: Salted cod in a sauce of tomato, onions, galic. chillie ( sometimes ), powdered shrimp shells and various other ingredients. It tends to vary by country, region and family. The best cod comes from Norway and they often put the Norwegian flag on the packet. As to the ingredients some of hard boiled egg, olives, red peppers, boiled Jersey new potatoes ( called cambrai ), currents. The cod must be soaked for a few hours changing the water now and then till it doesn‚Äôt taste salty.

Then cooked.

Turkey: This may be served in the American style, mashed potatoes, cranberry sauce, etc, but not often. Usually it is soaked in wine and roasted. Served with potato, apple, pineapple in mayo, salad etc. Baguettes.

Desserts: Fruit tart.

Romeritos: These look and taste like grass.

They are boiled and put in a mole sauce with shrimps, nopal cactus, and
potatoes.They grow in marshy soil and take a long time to prepare as you have to pull out the woody bits by hand,I like them and may make them, not decided yet.

Supermarkets also sell a roast pork loin that has a red sort of sauce and tastes smokey and sweet. Very popular, and sometimes runs out.

Well then we get to midnight and people go to the crib and maybe sing a carol or two and a bit of praying if you like. The observant observer would notice that at this point the crib is a little different. In general cribs are not at all biblically correct per say. There are always three kings ( bible says they didn‚Äôt come until 18 months later ), shepherds get missed out. Sheep are usually there, and the donkey is ‚Äúde rigueur‚Äù. The holy family, and an angel ( presumed Gabriel, not biblical ). One vital actor is missing to whit ‚Äúthe Christ Child‚Äù who makes appearance at midnight on the dot. More praying etc then back to the gin and tonics. The party then lasts until what ever time. Much like New Years Eve. Many people have a a large clan ( this is a catholic country ). But due to the house being small with set out the party in the carport. ( or maybe the street ), which is quite social.

So, you see, the crib is pretty central. Santa still comes later, gifts in a sack, or under a tree. But it‚Äôs not over yet. In many countries 12th night is celebrated, and here it‚Äôs pretty big. Gifts are given again, symbolic of the three kings. This time they are often of a practical nature, new jumper, school bag etc. 12th night was once a big thing in the UK, remember, Shakespeare wrote about it, but now it hardly gets a look in. There are twelve days of christmas, and a partridge in a pear tree. Christmas ends on the 6th of January, which is when I put the trimmings back into the box and ponder what to do with the tree, while most people regard christmas to have ended on New Year‚Äôs Day.

Traditional for this time of year is the rosca del los reyes. A sweet bread with candied fruit about 30 cm in diameter in the shape of a flat doenut ( crown ). headline: A Letter From A Merida
teaser: Will you send one?
content:
A Letter From A Merida
 By dave
 4 December 2024
I have long been fan of the works of Alistair Cooke, as you may deduce from the title. As young as 10 or so I remember looking forward to thursday nights on Radio 4, ( or was it the Home service ). I would settle down, often in bed and listen to ‚ÄúA Letter From America‚Äù. If was from these broadcasts that I developed interest in America, it‚Äôs tradition, peoples, history and so on. As Churchill said, and he said many things, ‚Äúwe are two peoples separated by a common language‚Äù. From here I developed an admiration of America, as an ideal, if not so in practice. The symbolism, the spirit and the idea of people starting again deciding among themselves how to organize a society. I later came to learn how much of this was taken from the French revolution, and how most of the founders were British. The constitution, I would argue was and is the greatest achievement of that country. I has been the inspiration of many a new country with its Bill of Rights, and parliamentary organization. In particular, the States are sovereign and there does exist mechanism to join or to succeed from the federation.

Cooke‚Äôs style was to often to set out his stall on such and such a topic in q roundabout way. I remember one about heat waves, or one about shoes, holiday time etc. Usually some mundane topic that Cooke would bring to life in my imagination. Slowly, slowly, he would expand on this, its history a few amazing facts , like a good journalist Cooke would tease along his audience with a few nibbles which then lead the way to his main thesis. There was some delight for me, how he got to his main topic which was often political news or common polemic, or world affairs and America‚Äôs action and reaction. I don‚Äôt know if Cooke invented this style of delivery, maybe not. It was as if you knew he was sneaking up on you from behind, with a red herring up his sleeve.

I have always consumed my Cooke over the airways of the radio, though I think I have on occasion spotted him on TV or in print, and I‚Äôm sure I don‚Äôt need to look far to find the printed word, but he had such a measured and smooth verbal manner that this is how I remember him best.


It‚Äôs out of this admiration that I partly developed my own style of writing. Indeed, I write best when I don‚Äôt know what I‚Äôm going to say, and then end up surprising myself and the reader.

And so I find myself now, proving my own point, as this not at all the blog post I intended to write. Not the topic I had in mind when I sat down at at the keyboard.
Anyway, I kept my powder dry. I can can write my ‚ÄúLetter from A Merida‚Äù another time. Watch this space.

He died at age 95.


No, it‚Äôs not about them.

The Art of the Interview
 By dave
 2 December 2024
Here I refer and give my thoughts on interviews, of the Job Kind. Media interviews, vox pop etc are fish of another kettle. Most people will have experience of the job interview, it‚Äôs often the final hoop to jump thru before they take you on, or give you a trial period.

I feel myself to be well qualified to opine on this topic having filled the roles of both interviewer and interviewee many times in my working life, especially since much of it has been spent as a contractor in the IT industry, where jobs are short, or long, and unpredictable. One can be taken on for a quick job for a week or so, and having finished it in a day or two, then extended to do another little task until three years later there you are still on a week‚Äôs notice either way, during which time you have been called on to interview other people to build up your little empire. Then it‚Äôs time to move on.

I‚Äôm sure many an MSc thesis has been ‚Äúearned‚Äù on the efficacy of interviewing in employee selection in all industries, and I seem to remember it comes out as no better than picking a name from a hat, but also many a PhD founded on improving the hit rate.( I‚Äôm suddenly reminded of that scene from ‚ÄúThe Office‚Äù where David Brent throws half the C.V‚Äôs in the bin because he ‚Äúdoesn‚Äôt want to work with unlucky people‚Äù).

So here‚Äôs my take on sitting both sides of the desk.

I was lucky enough to get taken on for the first job interview that I had. Not counting Saturday jobs etc. I had written to the firm as it was in my chosen field ( IT ) and it was just a block or so from where I lived. The joy of walking to work. As often happens tho they were to move office soon after I joined. I have always enjoyed the predictability and unpredictability of working with computers ( programming ), and a software house was a great place to start.

I found that my training period consisted of ‚Äúlisten to Tony‚Äù ( my project leader ), and ‚Äúread that manual‚Äù.
This was an excellent first lesson, and it served me well then, and many times after. Anyway, back to the subject.

Interviews come in great variety from soft chats, where you know you got the job, to real grillings, to just going thru the motions cos they got somebody better suited. I have on quite a few occasions gotten a callback after a week, from the job agent saying ‚Äúoh X has let them down, he didn‚Äôt really have the experience‚Ä¶ can you come in tomorrow?‚Äù. Sometimes you know that the interview is going nowhere, so it‚Äôs best to tell the other person that and not waste time. I remember one in Nottingham I think, where I told the interviewer that the agent had misunderstood the requirement and that I couldn‚Äôt or didn‚Äôt want to do the job. He seemed relieved and said ‚Äúsorry you had to come all this way‚Äù, ‚Äúno problem‚Äù, I said, ‚Äúchance to do some christmas shopping before the shops close‚Äù. ‚Äù Yeah‚Äù, he said, ‚ÄúI think I can get off early now and do some myself‚Äù.

I have to say a few words about the dreaded psychological test ordered up by the human resources of companies big enough to have them. I seems obvious what the questions are meant to be about. The old chestnut of three drawings. One in a disco, one at a dinner party and one in lonely attic reading book by candlelight. Your tendency to extrovert, or introvert. Others equally asinine. I recall one such test where afterward they scored it on the spot and the interviewer said, ‚Äúyou seem to be an introvert, but don‚Äôt worry. I‚Äôm pretty introverted myself, but I‚Äôm able to flex‚Äù. This was in pre ‚Äúrise of the nerds‚Äù days. Such tests are simple to game, and I would have thought ‚Äúno mates‚Äù goes with the job ( in IT ), but I could go on, and I won‚Äôt.

Often I would get a logic ‚Äúgotcha‚Äù type of question asked of me. In pre social media days there just a few going around. Doing that thing with three piles of hoops ( ‚ÄúTower of Hanoi‚Äù ) , one with shunting trains round a track, and one with two sticks and a bit of string. The thing to do was to rub one‚Äôs chin and pretend it was new to you, then fiddle about a bit, then ‚Äúsolve‚Äù it.

I will also present another technique I would adopt. If I was asked about my expertise in general I would say I had a good idea of this or that, ( which I did ), but that ‚Äúcoms‚Äù was not my strong suit. I would then be asked a few questions on ‚Äúcoms‚Äù, which at the time I had just been on an excellent training course and understood very well. Just saying, I‚Äôm sure I didn‚Äôt invent that technique.

Finally I want to relate the best interview I ever had.

I arrived, the manager met me, shook the hand, and said something like ‚Äúdo you know about XYZ and all that bullshit? Yes I‚Äôm sure you do. Now, this is your desk, you sit here, we‚Äôll pay what you asked for, can you come in tomorrow and start?‚Äù

Short and sweet.

And ‚Äúyes‚Äù I did.

content:
In an earlier post I alluded to the names of our border collie dogs, the senior of which is Sheba. She was so named after an old dog of my mother‚Äôs, but in turn this dog was named for a Hollywood Movie ‚ÄúCome Back, Little Sheba‚Äù. Sheba disappears months before the start of the film and never appears. It is implied that Sheba is presumed dead. It stars Burt Lancaster, and Shirley Booth, who got a Best Actress Oscar in 1953 for it. I began to wonder if there is a term for such characters and yes Gemini. informed me thus

Yes, there is! That type of character is called an offstage character or an unseen character.

These characters are important to the plot and the development of other characters, even though the audience never actually sees them. They might be mentioned in dialogue, have actions attributed to them, or even influence the events of the play.

Here are some examples of famous offstage characters:

Godot in ‚ÄúWaiting for Godot‚Äù: The title character is the most famous example of an offstage character, whose unseen presence drives the entire play.
Mr. Wickham‚Äôs father in ‚ÄúPride and Prejudice‚Äù: While the character of Mr. Wickham is onstage, his father, who worked for Mr. Darcy‚Äôs father, is only mentioned in dialogue. However, the elder Mr. Wickham‚Äôs past relationship with the Darcy family is crucial to understanding Wickham‚Äôs motivations.
Rose‚Äôs fianc√© in ‚ÄúThe Importance of Being Earnest‚Äù: Though never seen, Cecily‚Äôs imaginary betrothed, Ernest, plays a significant role in the comedic plot.
Offstage characters can serve a variety of purposes, such as:

Creating intrigue and suspense: The audience might wonder about their identity or motivations.
Developing other characters: Interactions with or discussions about the unseen character can reveal traits and motivations of the onstage characters.
Advancing the plot: Their actions, though offstage, can drive the events of the play.
Now as to Godot , it is a reworking by Samuel Beckett of his original work in French En attendant Godot.

It is alleged that originally Godot was meant to appear half way through the play, but the actor playing Godot failed to appear and so the two characters, Vladimir and Estragon were left to adlib the rest of the play. True? I doubt it but I would love it to be so.

Adding to the AI effort I can think of Mr Papadopoulos, in Coronation Street who is referred to by Mr Swindley ( Arthur Lowe ). Papadopoulos is a greek clothing magnate who owns Miami Modes. Swindley is the manager.

Again Arthur Lowe in Dad‚Äôs Army, Mrs Mannering is never seen.

Google gives us

King Laius in Oedipus Rex: An offstage character in Sophocles‚Äôs play who is a driving force for action
Jason‚Äôs bride in Medea: An offstage character in Euripides‚Äôs play
Rosaline in Romeo and Juliet: An offstage character in Shakespeare‚Äôs play who highlights the predicament of the two lovers
Off stage characters also exists in books ( again AI gives us )

Boo Radley in ‚ÄúTo Kill a Mockingbird‚Äù: Boo is a recluse who never leaves his house, but his presence looms large over the novel. He becomes a source of fascination and fear for the children, and his actions ultimately save Jem and Scout.

Mrs. Haverford in ‚ÄúRebecca‚Äù: The deceased first wife of Maxim de Winter, Rebecca is a powerful offstage character whose presence haunts the narrator and Manderley. Her influence shapes the entire plot, even though she is already dead.

Snape‚Äôs mother in the ‚ÄúHarry Potter‚Äù series: Eileen Prince, Severus Snape‚Äôs mother, is only mentioned in passing and through memories, but her difficult relationship with his father and her magical abilities are crucial to understanding Snape‚Äôs character and motivations.

I would add that in 1984 O‚ÄôBrien plays a major part in the narrative, but it is unsure that he actually exists.

For most of Atlas Shrugged we are unsure if John Galt exists, even though he drives the plot. ( yes, he appears, after a few 1000 pages üòâ ).

That‚Äôs about it, but if you can think of any I‚Äôve missed please leave a comment. Ta.

headline: Life Thru a Lens
teaser: A new perspective. Good
content:
Life Through a Lens A recent chat with I can't remember who about the Robbie Williams movie "A Better Man" caused me to pick a random Robbie track, to listen to. Chance threw me "Life Thru a Lens", and though it's not one his more famous efforts, there was a nifty tune.

I wondered what it was all about? Fresh from my recent bout of cinematic Robbiemania, I looked for some meaning in the lyrics. It seemed obvious this was about fame, publicity, image, photographers, paparazzi.

Maybe Robbie had penned this as he was experiencing the price of fame? Who knows? But then something else clicked, and it came to me that life is indeed often lived through a lens, not literally, but metaphorically.

To briefly skate over some ancient philosophies, was it Plato who said we live in a cave and just see the shadows of reality as people pass outside?

Some Buddhists dispute that there is any "reality at all", while another group of Buddhists believe that "reality" is all there is. Reality is what you make it, how you look at it.

My very good friend Rob Aston, has tried to explain something similar a few times. Rob is a Zoomologist, who asks us to consider Zooming out to zoom in, to achieve the right perspective.

I had struggle a little with the idea what you had to zoom out, maybe due to the book being called zoom-out, because sometimes you need to zoom in, sometimes on a different axis. Time, space etc. It suddenly fell into place, if I thought of life not a being a zoomable lens but a lens in general.

So, if you have a camera, you often buy many lenses, macro, zoom, pin hole, fish eye. You may buy filters, UV, cloud filters. Some people see things through rose coloured glasses, some through a glass, darkly.

Beyond this we experience life through sounds, vision, touch, the metaphor extends.

Change the lens, change the perception, change the reality.

Here's an example.

The Japanese tea ceremony is an ancient ritual, and through the eyes and experiences of a master the acts of drawing the water, heating it to the correct temperature etc. I remember a description of the water boiling though various stages, quite poetic, till it reaches fish eye bubbles then it is ready.

A physical chemist ( like me ) has a different explanation, of how water goes though many liquid phases, the kinetics how it flows and heats, conduction, convection, radiation. The same phenomenon different lens.

What is the nature of ritual? What is the nature of ritual magik? Crowley's thesis, did he really communicate with Aiwass? Or did he meet his own subconscious? The fascinating story of Madam Blavatsky, Jack Parsons, the weird tale that is the auto hagiography of this remarkable beast.

Robert Anton Wilson Prometheus rising, I recall, and the inclusion of various exercises, "look at the floor you will find money".

Back to my old idea of the "Self Help Cookbook", could be now woven in, but why stop there? people want help with lifestyle diet, exercise habits. Diet, health, medicine, politics. The camera lens and the echo chamber.

"Life Though a Lens" would in itself be just another lens, another metaphor.

I don't know much about theology, philosophy, psychiatry, but it would be fascinating to find out.

There's a lot of fruit hanging on this tree, where to pick first?

headline: K-E-Y-N-S-H-A-M
teaser: That's Keynsham spelled K-E-Y-N-S-H-A-M Keynsham Bristol
content:
When I was a little boy I would dread going to bed. My parents would stay up, of course and watch TV programs for an "adult audience", among others. My bed time was based it seems on Victorian ideas of how much sleep a child needed, mixed with getting me out of the way for a few hours.

These hours were deadly boring especially since it was still light at 6.00, and I dreaded the coming of the hour. I was not permitted to read, as it would damage my eyes, they said, and so the solitary confinement weighed heavy on me.

That was until my cousin was allowed sleep over and showed me the magic of a flashlight and the possibility to sneak one in and read under the blankets. Thus began my love of reading, and self education. My father bought me an encyclopedia, with the promise of buying me one each week but sadly Aardvark to Azimuth was all I ever got. But anyway I had now discovered a public library a short walk away, and could no longer be held back.

The next game changer was the arrival in the house of an orange portable radio with a very big dial that with fresh batteries was capable of telling me about the wide World out there, long before the web arrived.

My cousin introduced us to pirate radio, and Radio Luxemburg, the latter always confused me as the spoke English and had a lot of advertisements about how to win the football pools.

It was thus I learned how to spell Keynsham, thats K-E-Y-N-S-H-A-M, Kenynsham, Bristol. They had to spell it out in case you spelled it Cainsham. but I think the post office would have noticed if it addressed to Horace Batchelor and delivered it anyway.

Before The Lottery when gambling was illegal people were able to gamble on the football results, or so called "pools". I think this was short for "pool betting" where all the bets went into a pool and somehow the winnings got shared out from those who had the best predictions. There were first dividends, and second dividends, and so on. I don't think anyone except Littlewoods understood how it worked. Well, Horace Batchelor, maybe he understood. If you sent your money to Horace in Keynsham he would place the bets for you according to his system. This was said to increase your odds of winning. He didn't share his system, you had to trust him. Horace took a percentage of all winnings, so he only won if you did. So to be fair maybe he did have the touch.

Another popular way to get rich was to answer the advertisement in the newspapers. Often titled "The Lazy Man's Way to Get Rich". You sent some money, and they would write back with a note saying "Do what I do". So technically that was correct, so long as you had a supply of suckers to keep answering the ad. Most people would be embarrassed to have been so stupid as to send money. Others would have placed their own advertisement. #scams ..

headline: Praise to the Engineer
teaser: I was musing about the word ‚Äúengineer‚Äù and what it means, and how it is often underappreciated, both in the word and in the practitioner.
content:
#engineering

I was musing about the word ‚Äúengineer‚Äù and what it means, and how it is often underappreciated, both in the word and in the practitioner. As a youth I was very interested in science, and I still am. I looked at it as my future career and thus studied to a higher level. One would meet on occasions with chemical engineers coming to share breaks in the canteen, we would often mingle and converse. I was a student chemist, and I imagined I would one day discover something and be famous for it, even though poorly paid, I could work in my lab and change the world from my fume cupboard. As time went on a more lofty aspiration was to study theoretical chemistry and avoid the acid burns. ( Also I must confess to an experiment in the fume cupboard with peracid acid and iodine where the magnetic stirrer got bogged down. I stepped away for something and heard a thunderous bang!! Much of the apparatus had gone up the chimney ). Anyway, I was not good enough at maths to think I could get a postdoc in it, so I graciously put down my beaker and found another career. But still, I regarded an engineer as second rate, more concerned with practical stuff, like making engines etc. ( ever hear of quantum mechanics? ). Or Casey Jones?

And so it was, until we bought a house. It was a big one, large plot, and in basic good shape, but needed a generous amount of refurbishment. We decided that whilst walls were being plastered we could take a few out and build a few new ones. A swimming pool on the cards, and a small apartment at the back for guests. New floors and my dream kitchen. It was not exactly a blank piece of paper, more of a canvas to paint by numbers.

Enter‚Ä¶ Philipe !!!.

An architect was needed, but coming dear and me being tight we wanted a junior or maybe a student. Keen, and cheap. The architect‚Äôs job was to be to design, draw up plans and deal with The Maestro. As luck would have it there was a gang working on a project just up the street, so we went and asked when they would finish. The fresh faced architect happened to be there and said his dad was an architect, he was an intern in the firm and was looking for his next gig. We said to jump in the car and come look at the house we bought a few days ago and so he did. He had worked a few projects with the Maestro Don Mees and would recommend him if he got the job. Philippe quoted a good price provided we did part of the work which involved buying and choosing materials. Sort of quantity surveyor. Philippe would come once a week to monitor progress, check the materials, check the payments to Don Mees and deal with plans, permits and all that jazz.

Don Mees was a tall robust man of later years who had earned his title, and reined in terror over a gang of between 5 and 20 depending on his other projects. A mix of regulars, specialists,and day labourers. He turned out to be very approachable and friendly.

On the Friday, when Philipe came, we would plan out the work for the next few weeks. This was where the fun bit came. I soon built up a good rapport with Phillippe and enjoyed creating our dream house with him. All was negotiable. I remember sitting on the bog and stretching my hand to be sure I could reach the toilet paper. Everything done to the inch. All great fun. My plans for a swimming pool were changed when Philippe suggested a better place to build it. The kitchen slabs to suit my stature. The cupboards made from local hard wood, based a photo I saw on Pinterest. You get the idea. Once the idea was there Phillippe would check feasibility, materials, costs and explain the practicality and we would reach a joint decision.

Philippe was an engineer, though he could work out stresses, shapes, what material did what etc. He was not a scientist, but he was an engineer. From that I learned respect for the engineer.

Here‚Äôs a paragraph from Robert A. Heinlein‚Äôs ‚ÄúThe Notebooks of Lazarus Long‚Äù where he reflects on engineers:

‚ÄúAn engineer is someone who can do for a dime what any fool can do for a dollar. The real genius of an engineer doesn‚Äôt lie in what he knows, but in what he can do with what he knows. An engineer isn‚Äôt just a technician or a designer; he‚Äôs a problem solver who uses science, mathematics, and imagination to make the world work better. He turns the dreams of others into reality, often under constraints of time, money, and materials. To engineer is to create, to innovate, and to improve upon the human condition through practical application‚Äù.

Years afterwards I would reflect that medical doctors are engineers, combining a mix of constraints to produce and agreed result with their patients. ( Well, the best ones are ). Cooks are engineers, balancing the budget, healthiness, family food preferences, negotiating the myriad of decisions in making lunch. In a sense we are all engineers, with various levels of experience and science. I later became a software engineer, and I think that term is often misunderstood. I‚Äôve sailed between a rock and a hard place many times but never struck bottom.

Anyway, over budget and over time estimate we got our dream house, and very pleased we are. In fact it was under budgets by my person estimates, Philipe over promised and I knew how it goes. We used Philippe again, years later when I designed a small out building, which am very proud of.

The last thing I remain to say on this subject is that his name was not Philipe, but it was Ernesto. He put me right pretty soon, but I continued to call him Philipe because I knew it annoyed him.

content:
There a small book by Primo Levi that I‚Äôve enjoyed dipping into now and then over the years. It‚Äôs called ‚ÄúOther People‚Äôs‚Äô Trades‚Äù. I had almost forgotten it until I was scratching my head to think of a title for this post. It‚Äôs a collection of essays describing various jobs and trades. I must read it again soon.

Back to the subject then. I‚Äôm fascinated by languages and the derivation of words, and so no surprised I‚Äôve been wondering about names. Almost everyone has a name, or maybe two or three, and how we came by them is an interesting question. Now here I‚Äôm talking about surnames in particular, they must have an origin and maybe they evolve through time. I‚Äôll confine this to English speaking names, but it would be useful to compare these to other cultures in the world.

Now, let‚Äôs start with Smith.And why not. It has long been the most common name surname in English speaking countries. There people have a christian name or two and a surname, or maybe more than one if they are multi-barreled. Or should be say a given name and a forename, just to be more inclusive. So John Smith. Someone‚Äôs lacking in imagination, still have met quite a few John Smiths all look like you would expect a John Smith to look. So I guess years ago being a Smith was pretty big cheese what with all those horses to shoe. Taylor springs to mind ( John Also ), Sigourney Weaver , Max Miller, Ginger Baker, Butcher, Fletcher, Cooper ( made barrels ), Carpenter ( John again ) Thatcher ( you know who ) and Harry Potter. You could populate a village thus. Then we have people who have rich blood, King, Lord, Knight. But what about the Farmers?? So many of them. Mr Farmer??

On to colours. I‚Äôve met a Mr Black and a Dr White. There‚Äôs and Earl Grey, a Huey Green, and many a Joe Brown. But where‚Äôs Mr Blue? Miss Yellow? Master Orange ( Take That! ). But like a set of Cluedo pieces.

Now on to the sons. There are Johnsons, Petersons, Robertsons, Andersons, but no daughters. Explained by the patriarchy and the tradition of passing the family name down the male line.

Sometimes names are derived from towns ( Tony Blackburn ) or cities ( Michael York ) or even countries. Dawn French, Jules Holland,

Animals, apart from John Bull, James Whale, Michael Fish, and I did once know a guy called Rob Chicken.

( You shouldn‚Äôt laugh ).

Well, that‚Äôs about it. #words

content:
Apart from the comic effect of the now well politically incorrect Little Britain, whilst recently trying to correct an issue I had with some company website, ( now fixed thanks ), I remember times in my Geekhood when it seemed impossible that the computer was right and I was wrong. Every programmer knows the feeling like they did everything right, and it was working a moment ago and it come up with what seems like a bug. You look at the code for the obvious errors, not there. You roll back a version, either that works for not, but as you put back the changes it still won‚Äôt work. After to some struggle you have to admin to defeat and ask the guy or gal in the next desk to take a look for you. Often as you explain the problem you talk yourself into the answer, or maybe your desk mate can say ‚Äúoh they changed the compiler last week‚Äù , or ‚Äúyou‚Äôre running the old version, idiot!‚Äù. A fresh pair of eyes. Often where you are looking isn‚Äôt where you should look at all. But sometimes, just sometimes, you can‚Äôt crack the problem. Random errors are the worse. Works then doesn‚Äôt, then works again. There is a sort of rule of thumb.

Blame the user ‚Äì usually yourself .

Blame the data ‚Äì check the inputs and outputs, eyeball the data .

Blame your code.

Blame the library.

Blame the compiler ‚Äì now I‚Äôve seen this happen a couple of times. I was the guy in the next desk and I was shown some Cobol that should have worked but it threw an error at runtime. Now I don‚Äôt know how I knew this, maybe I read to many manuals, but I saw the subroutine was being call from an address which was not on a word boundary. An easy mistake to make, but hard to spot.

Blame the operating system. ‚Äì maybe the disk is full, or there‚Äôs a known bug in windows, or a quirk in Chrome, these things happen, or a display driver, but not often.

Blame the hardware ‚Äì You can check this by running on another machine.

Then you‚Äôre stumped.

I‚Äôve only been stumped twice in my life. At a total loss. But hello, hang on, I don‚Äôt like to be beaten!

I don‚Äôt know if I came up with the answers probably not, but here are the situations.

A mini computer for a hotel accounts dept kept going wrong. Crashes, corrupt memory, random errors. They changed the disks, Upgraded the OS. Still no fix. They manufacturer changed all the memory. Still no go. They changed the machine, still no go. They gave up and flew back to Texas.

I was a junior programmer and was sent to spend Christmas in a nice hotel in London so I could be a face to blame when it went wrong. It didn‚Äôt go wrong. Once. I went home, it went wrong again.

Answer. The office was on the second floor. There was a butcher on the first floor with big meat cutting saws. Over Christmas he didn‚Äôt work. The computer did. The solution was to build a Faraday cage around the machine room. Solved.

Second case. An international airport had a similar problem. Different computer company. Worked and then didn‚Äôt, but it always seemed to fail on Thursdays. Again environment. They had a training radar school on Thursdays. Easy fix. aluminum foil in the case ( so they told me ).

So if you‚Äôre ever stumped take comfort in the fact that cosmic rays can knock electrons out of chips. This is rare, but with so many computers in the world, this just might be the excuse you‚Äôre looking for.

headline: Systems Analyst
teaser: These were the days of wearing a suit and carrying a briefcase. Mine had a biro, some pencils, a sharpener, a plastic flowchart stencil, and a bag of sandwiches inside. I was so very proud to be at work. I even had a haircut.
content:
The rise and fall of the systems analyst. =========================================

#computers

Back in the stone ages when computers ran on pebbles, and you programmed them telling a slave what to do, round about 1975 or so I started work as a junior programmer. I worked for a software house with offices down the road.

These were the days of wearing a suit and carrying a briefcase. Mine had a biro, some pencils, a sharpener, a plastic flowchart stencil, and a bag of sandwiches inside. I was so very proud to be at work. I even had a haircut.

Introduced to my coworkers who were a friendly bunch. Most had been thrown out of work from boring clerical jobs due to the rise of the mainframe computer and as often happens they were repurposed as programmers.

These were the days of coding sheets being sent to be punched up, flow charts, printouts, compilations ( once a day ), and systems analysts.

I was never quite sure were people had been working before, and what the role was. IBM ruled our roust and had some sort of methodology called The Waterfall.

Someone at some point decided a system was needed, and got the funds to have it created. These were the days of program suites and batch programming, as opposed to the multifunctional solutions today.

A system spec was produced by the chief analyst, who give it to underlings to produce the various program specs to give to the programmer to code and test. The analyst worked with the customer and would iterate the specs.

Specs were written in pencil on paper! Yes. As were the programs. Sometimes some hotshot would program with a a biro! We wrote in Cobol ( you may have guessed ).

Once working and tested the program went back to the analyst for testing, and later when the suite was ready began system testing, and fixing, until it was accepted. Then it went into maintenance.

And so it was.

The analyst knew little of programming and the technology and the best way to do things.

Analysts were well paid and all programmers aspired one day to get such a role.

Few succeeded, gatekeeping was rife.

Anyway the years rolled by. There came the mini computer, and then the PC and slowly the role of the analyst diminished so that eventually we were down to a statement of requirements some coding standards or frameworks and away we went.

I'm sure big companies like Google still have some sort of methodologies, but I was thinking today of rewriting some of my code from scratch using a chatbot, and thinking how best to prompt it. To keep control of the design and reign it in so it didn't spew code all the time. To be honest almost like a program spec, like what I used to work from every day.

Still there are no systems analysts today,..... oh wait! Maybe I'm achieving my ambitions at last.

It‚Äôs hard to imagine for an outsider how important the virgin is. I went on the bus. So the 12th will be Sheba Guadalupe‚Äôs birthday. Now back to what Intended to write about when I sat down, this for us is a date that we like to be ready for christmas by. Like the old question ‚Äúare you ready for christmas?‚Äù which I never know how to answer. And so it is that I now am getting the materials, design, free time ( haha ) to start the construction of the crib. In mexican ‚ÄúNacimiento‚Äù. content:
II was talking to my significant other this morning over coffee and chanced to mention a fat gentlemen who was often outside our house at 5.00 am in the morning hanging around looking at his phone and leaning on the wall at the corner of our block. We long since learned he was a bus inspector who logged all the ‚Äúkiller‚Äù busses that passed. In fact there was nothing sinister about him at all.

My S.O. is in fact not a native english speaker tho she does very well with my laziness and frustration speaking Spanish. As often happens this provoked a discussion of the word ‚Äúsinister‚Äù which I am sure she was uninterested in, but she did a good impression as always, to the contrary.

I jumped to my opportunity to be able to explain the entomology, as I remembered it, that it is from the Latin ‚Äúsinister‚Äù which means ‚Äúleft handed‚Äù. This provoked an explication that ‚Äúdexter‚Äù means right handed, from which we get the word ‚Äúdexterous‚Äù. A quick detour into how the TV series Dexter was very entertaining for about six seasons until his sister turned into a killer and the shark was well and truly jumped ‚Ä¶ with a vaulting pole.

By then I was off to the races, as to how left handed people were discriminated against to the point that they were said to be in league with Satan, and often ( or just once ) burned at the stake. Thru history there have been famous ‚Äúlefties‚Äù, tho I can only think of Napoleon, and Paul McCartney at the moment. Then without need for a lefty rights matter campaign a supply of special left handed products have come to market but to economic factors that you can charge a lot of money to take advantage of such afflicted people.

The classic example is golf clubs, i.e the sticks to play the game. These used to attract a good premium.I was set to wonder what portion of the word population is left handed, and off the top of my head I guess 2%, which I will later check on Wikipedia. From there a list of left handed things.

A tin opener. Not the simple up and down, but the butterfly type.
Maybe a corkscrew is a bit uncomfortable, I‚Äôm not sure. (??).
Scissors or anything like ( secuteuse , is French ).
A guitar, as to which I have quite a lot to say. Paul McCartney, Ringo Starr and Jimmy Hendrix spring to mind, and I could say much more on the topic of lefty music, but another time‚Ä¶.

A quick visit to Lefty‚Äôs the Left Hand Store | Everything for the Left-Hander will give you a basic idea of
what there is. To save you the trouble, there are left handed pencil sharpeners ( and pencils!! ), left handed gloves ( of course‚Ä¶ ), left handed cooking spoons, spatulas etc.

So from there I ventured into handedness, and how the mathematical term is ‚ÄúChirality‚Äù, and then onto how I have studied the subject. I have a degree in chemistry, where handedness is of great import, and I could go on about there being more than two hands involved in the situation, which lead on to my postgrad research involving crystallography, and how there are 230 or types of crystal, but no more and no less. This is a mathematical constraint and comes out of space group theory, and how there are only 17 types of wallpaper ( or so theory had it till Roger Penrose got into tiling ). All this stuff fascinating
to me, boring to Magis, anyway, time to take the dogs for a walk.

headline: One Trick Words
teaser: A definitive list
content:
There are quite a few words that can be classified as ‚Äúone trick words‚Äù, i.e. they are always ( or almost always ) found in conjunction with another given word. i.e. did you ever hear of a toothcomb that wasn‚Äôt fine? You may have been cheesed off, but who was ever cheesed on? You get the idea. I first came across the term many years ago on a website ‚Äúrichard.tangle-wood.uk‚Äù which I would assume was a personal page that Richard tacked onto a company website so he didn‚Äôt need to pay for, what with in those days internet use being somewhat expensive. This page no longer exists along with a few other wordplay type pages that Richard had made. So credit Richard, it‚Äôs only fair, but I‚Äôve tried to make a definitive list from his and other sources, along with a few trivial amendments here‚Äôs my ‚Äúdefinitive list‚Äù.

Aback: A person can be taken by it.

Abdabs: are invariably the screaming kind.

Ado: ‚Ä¶ not only is ‚Äòado‚Äô always further , but it is only mentioned when ‚Äòwithout‚Äô, as in ‚Äòwithout further ado‚Äô. The phrase ‚Äòmuch ado‚Äô occurs in the title of a 16th century play but does not otherwise occur in modern English.

Afield: Something can be ‚Äòfarther afield‚Äô, or, at a pinch, ‚Äòfurther afield‚Äô.

Aforethought: Only ‚Äòmalice‚Äô can be ‚Äòaforethought‚Äô. Aggrandising: Has to be self aggrandising. Akimbo: Only ‚Äòarms‚Äô can be ‚Äòakimbo‚Äô. I am aware that some degenerate souls use ‚Äòlegs akimbo‚Äô, but the dictionary definition is: ‚ÄúOf the arms: In a position in which the hands rest on the hips and the elbows are turned outwards‚Äù.

Amends: You can make them.

Amok: ‚Ä¶ can only be run

Ante: ‚Ä¶ can only be ‚Äòupped‚Äô

Applecart: We don‚Äôt want to upset it.

Aspersions: Can only be cast. (But see note below.)

Askance: ‚Ä¶ you can look it.

Bandied: ‚Ä¶ about

Bated: ‚Ä¶ breath

Be-all: The be-all is also the end-all.

Beavering: ‚Ä¶ away

Bended: Only a knee can be bended. Anything else would be bent.

Betide: Only woe can betide.

Betwixt: Things that are betwixt are also between.

Billy-o: You can do things like it

Bogged: You can only get it down

Bounden: ‚Ä¶ duty

Cahoots: Always in with, never out of.

Cheesed: ‚Ä¶ off

Codger: A codger is invariably old.

Daylights: Daylights can only be plural if they are The Living, and being scared, beaten or otherwise moved Out Of someone.

Dint: as in, ‚Äúby dint of‚Äù

Disrepute: ‚Ä¶ is never seen without ‚Äòinto‚Äô. Brought into, fall into or even slide into; but always ‚Äòinto‚Äô.

Dolled: ‚Ä¶ up

Doff: ‚Ä¶ one‚Äôs hat (or synonym, such as cap)

Dribs: ‚Ä¶ are inseparable from drabs.

Druthers: ‚Ä¶ are always counterfactual.

Dudgeon: One can be in it, but only if its high.

Dulcet: tones

Extenuating: Only ‚Äòcircumstances‚Äô can be ‚Äòextenuating‚Äô.

Falutin (sic): is always high.

Fledged: Was anything ever ‚Äòpartially‚Äô fledged?

Fobbed: ‚Ä¶ off

Fro: ‚ÄúFro‚Äù, as in ‚Äúto and fro‚Äù, is an abbreviated form of ‚Äúfrom‚Äù. But it is an abbreviation that is only used with ‚Äúto and‚Äù.

Gyp: ‚Ä¶ can be given, but not taken (except in Cambridge and Durham, where a ‚Äúgyp‚Äù is a college servant). Gyp should not be confused with gip, an American colloquialism.

Hackles: They rise, or in the passive, they may be raised. But they are never lowered.

Halcyon: Only ‚Äòdays‚Äô can be halcyon.

Handcart: You can go to hell in one.

Hawing: Anyone ‚Äúhawing‚Äù has, in fact, been ‚Äúhumming and hawing‚Äù, if they are in Britain, or ‚Äúhemming and hawing‚Äù, if in the States.

Het: ‚Ä¶ up

Hived: ‚Ä¶ off

Honcho: The only kind of honcho is a head honcho.

Hoar: ‚Ä¶ frost

Hove: ‚ÄúHove into view‚Äù, yes. ‚ÄúHove into the living room‚Äù, or anywhere else, no.

Hue: And cry

Hunker: ‚Ä¶ down

Immemorial: Only ‚Äòtime‚Äô can be ‚Äòimmemorial‚Äô.

Inroads: You can make them, into something.

Intents: can only be plural when used in the phrase ‚Äúto all intents and purposes‚Äù.

Madding: The only thing you can do with the word ‚Äúmadding‚Äù is to make a literary allusion, as in ‚Äúfar from the madding crowd‚Äù. Even the title of the Thomas Hardy novel is a literary allusion to a previous poem by Thomas Gray.

Offing: Things can be in it

Outstay: Only a welcome can be outstayed.

Over-reach: If you‚Äôre going to do any over-reaching, you‚Äôll over-reach yourself.

Paraclete: The only thing to be done with the word ‚Äòparaclete‚Äô is point out that it applies to the Holy Spirit, in Christian theology.

Pease: ‚Ä¶ pudding

Petard: You can be hoist with one ‚Äì if it‚Äôs your own

Peter: Peter out, yes. But peter back in again? No!

Pikestaff: A thing can be as plain as one.

Plighting: ‚Ä¶ can only be done to one‚Äôs troth.

Pock: ‚Ä¶ mark

Poring: over

Pyrrhic: ‚Ä¶ victory

Quandary: ‚Ä¶ you can be in it

Raze: You can raze things to the ground, but you can‚Äôt raze them to anywhere else.

Retrick: ‚Ä¶ one‚Äôs beams. According to the dictionary, use of the word ‚Äúretrick‚Äù is ‚Äúalways with reference to Milton‚Äôs line ‚Ä¶ ‚Äòthe day-star ‚Ä¶retricks his beams‚Äô ‚Äú.

Riband: Only comes in blue.

Riddance: is invariably ‚Äògood‚Äô.

Rouser: The only sort is a rabble rouser.

Runcible: Runcible was originally a nonsense word coined by Edward Lear, but ‚Äòruncible spoon‚Äô was subsequently adopted to describe a three-pronged slotted spoon for eating pickles. By definition, therefore, only a spoon can be runcible.

Sandboy: You can be as happy as one.

Scrimp: Did anyone ever scrimp but not save?

Serried: ranks

Shebang: With the whole shebang, we are familiar. But a partial shebang ‚Ä¶

Shrift: Was anyone ever given long shrift?

Slake: Only a ‚Äòthirst‚Äô can be ‚Äòslaked‚Äô. ( edit never heard of slaked lime ? )

Slanging: ‚Ä¶ match

Sleight: ‚Ä¶ of hand

Snook: You can cock one.

Shored: ‚Ä¶ up

Spick: Was anything or anywhere ever spick but not span?

Squib: No-one ever mentions a squib unless it‚Äôs damp.

Stead: One can be stood in it, but only if it is good stead.

Staving: ‚Ä¶ off

Stoved: ‚Ä¶ in

Straitened: Only circumstances can be ‚Äòstraitened‚Äô, including financial circumstances.

Tabby: ‚Ä¶ cat

Tenterhooks: You can be on them

Thew: ‚Ä¶ and sinew

Tittle: This is the tittle of ‚Äònot one jot or tittle‚Äô. (‚ÄòTittle-tattle‚Äô is a hyphenated single word.)

Toeing: ‚Ä¶ the line ( not towing )

Toothcomb: The only kind of toothcomb is a fine toothcomb: but see the note below.

Tribulations: No-one has had ‚Äòtribulations‚Äô that weren‚Äôt preceded by ‚Äòtrials‚Äô since the time of Job.

Trice: You can do things in one

Trove: Is there any kind other than treasure?

Troth: you can pledge it

Ulterior: Only a ‚Äòmotive‚Äô can be ‚Äòulterior‚Äô.

Vantage: ‚Ä¶ point

Vested: ‚Ä¶ interest

Weft: I don‚Äôt know what it is, but it is always accompanied by ‚Äòwarp‚Äô.

Welled: ‚Ä¶ up

Wend: ‚Ä¶ your way, his way, its way ‚Ä¶

Whiling: ‚Ä¶ away

Wined: ‚Ä¶ and dined. You can‚Äôt do the former without the latter.

headline: Peoples Parliament

content:
Your blog entry presents a compelling and impassioned case for rethinking democracy in the UK, driven by a clear frustration with the current political system and a desire to empower ordinary citizens. I‚Äôll break down my reactions to your proposal for a ‚ÄúPeople‚Äôs Parliament‚Äù and offer some thoughts on its strengths, potential challenges, and areas that might benefit from further exploration.

How would you frame this to Channel 4‚Äîplay up the ‚Äúsilent king‚Äù critique as a rallying cry? And if the public did push for a patron later, who‚Äôd you hope they‚Äôd pick over Charles? This is locking into that raw, urgent energy you started with‚Äîlove to see where it lands!

headline: Let it Be a Cover
teaser: The Beatles were not the first to release "Let it Be"
content:
I think I have a pretty broad taste in music, I‚Äôll give anything a shot, if it sounds nice then I don‚Äôt much care if it‚Äôs country, rock, pop, classical etc etc etc. It‚Äôs nice to have some music when relaxing in the house, or working on something boring. When anyone might enquire what sort of music I like, to avoid the cliche ‚Äúeverything‚Äù, I will say it‚Äôs covers. And indeed this is true. As I see it the advantage of a cover is that it you have a favorite piece of music that you‚Äôve play to death and are getting a bit fed up, you may find a cover brings new life to your streaming collection. So before I continue I should define what is a cover. When an artist owns an original piece of music they have the right of first performance, which is logical because no one else knows about it. After the first significant public performance, or commercial release, the song comes up for grabs, and anyone can make a version and make money from it. So what about all this ‚Äúwhen X called Y to ask for permission to cover Z‚Äù type stories, this is a courtesy call it‚Äôs not required. When you do need leave it‚Äôs when you want to use it in another medium, like a jeans advert or a movie. The coverer is obliged to pay a royalty fee though an agency to the songs owner. Performing rights. Anyway, that‚Äôs the law as I think it is. In general it seems to be opinion that the original is best, but of course there may be other opinions. One famous oft quoted is that Jimi Hendrix covered ‚ÄúAll along the Watchtower‚Äù, by Bob Dylan, and many think Hendrix did a better version. It‚Äôs certainly different. Dylan was reported to say that he now plays it more like the Hendrix version.

headline: Copyright Jokes
teaser: It's way I tellem
content:
Jokes, well everybody likes a laugh, except of course people with no sense of humor, and I think there must be some people who have never laughed, except when they forced it as a result of group pressure.
Trying to explain to such folk results in a ‚Äúuh? Oh yeah, hehe‚Äù. It must be frustrating to never understand why people are making a cackling noise. I believe Freud wrote a book about it, I never read it, so I don‚Äôt know if it was funny. And again liberal arts PhD candidates regurgitate and research what makes a good joke. The results of which are of course repeated in the media. My usual reaction to ‚ÄúOfficially the funniest joke ever‚Äù is ‚Äúuh? Oh yeah, hehe‚Äù.

A FAQ is ‚Äúwhere do new jokes come from?‚Äù. When asked, comedians usually say something like ‚Äúthere are only seven basic jokes and they get retold a bit different‚Äù. Others say ‚Äúin the Universities.‚Äù Well, I don‚Äôt know. I frequently read new jokes on my fondle slab some raise a smile, and some a titter, and others get to laugh out loud on the Rickter scale. Jokes I‚Äôve heard before aren‚Äôt so funny, of course, but there are still a few that I always find amusing not that I can think of one such off the top of my head.

Who was the first person to tell a joke? We will never know, but the first person to tell such and such a joke, and one that is genuinely funny? I‚Äôm thinking maybe it happened by accident, and some though to copy it and write it on papyrus.

There‚Äôs a joke or two I‚Äôve told that I think I made up myself. Now, if this can be true I don‚Äôt know. Like Paul McCartney with ‚ÄúYesterday‚Äù, he kept asking people if it was original or had it been written by Beethoven or such? Leads me to copyright. I needed some pictures for my little app, I have in development. It‚Äôs a visual thing so I need some stock photos. Many on the internet bear a copyright notice so I‚Äôm more looking for public domain stuff. I asked an AI to make some, and enquired about who had the copyright. It hummed and aahed , so I didn‚Äôt get a clear answer. Here‚Äôs the real question‚Ä¶ if I tell an original joke, and I can prove it, do I have copyright? And can I enforce it? If I publish it in r/jokes and no one can come forward with prior claim should I receive a royalty when people use it online, or even down the pub? There are enough cases in the music industry, that X copied a few bars from Y and now Y want‚Äôs her cut. When is a joke to similar? or unique? ‚Äúan Englishman, an Irishman and a Scotsman‚Ä¶‚Äù, if I just change the nationalities is it a new joke?

I‚Äôm a thinking maybe there should be a web page ‚Äúoriginaljokes.com‚Äù say, where people could officially register their joke. And what about the guffaw grab which could ensue of people claiming old jokes as new? Similar to when the the internet started, someone registered mtv.com, and later sold it for big money.

So, as to my original jokes? What are they? Can I tell you?

I‚Äôm not sure ICANN. ( smile , groan, titter ).

headline: The Album that changed music
teaser:
most people have never heard it.....most people have never heard it, wind back to
 October 1968‚Ä¶ ‚ÄúSwitched-On Bach reached number 10 on the US Billboard 200 chart and topped the Billboard Classical Albums chart from 1969 to 1972. It started the techo-pop revolution
content:
The Album that really did change music! ( most people have never heard it )
 By dave
 29 November 2024
I‚Äôm a great fan of YouTube, in fact I like it so much I pay for it. Also I enjoy my music and listen to it a lot, and even play guitar and piano, time permitting. There are several channels that have run series of ‚ÄúThe Albums that changed music‚Äù, and enjoyable and entertaining as they are, they all seem to miss out on my pick. Tiz not Sgt Pepper, Pet Sounds, Dark side of the Moon etc. in fact I think I‚Äôve never heard tell of my choice from any of the big critics. Now this is starting to sound like one of those click bate things I get lured into on Google Discover, when they lead you on and on through dozens of popups, til you get to the end and realize you‚Äôve been had. Again.

Let‚Äôs go back to October 1968‚Ä¶

‚ÄúSwitched-On Bach reached number 10 on the US Billboard 200 chart and topped the Billboard Classical Albums chart from 1969 to 1972. By June 1974, it had sold over one million copies, and in 1986 became the second classical album to be certified platinum. In 1970, it won Grammy Awards for Best Classical Album, Best Classical Performance ‚Äì Instrumental Soloist or Soloists (With or Without Orchestra), and Best Engineered Classical Recording.‚Äù ( Wikipedia )

I remember hearing and loving it for the first time. The clarity and precision of the music fitted perfectly with Bach‚Äôs contrapuntal ( counterpoint ) style. The mathematical symmetry and bare bones of the production, Bach and the Moog synthesizer went together like a horse and carriage. I bought a copy on cassette due to not having a record player, and later the CD for its digital precision. Both of which are lost in the tea-chests of house moving. Sounds great on headphones!

Back to the point of my post, and how it did change music?

The Beatles were recording ‚ÄúLet It Be‚Äù at this time. They had already started experimenting with electronics and using the recording studio as a musical instruments in itself. Tape loops, echo chambers, music concrete. This things were at the time the property of musicians like Stockhausen, and Kraftwerk, not really accessible to the general public. By this time several musicians had acquired a synth, including George Harrison .

George Harrison (‚ÄúElectronic Sound‚Äù) , Bob Marley(‚ÄúStir it Up‚Äù), Stevie Wonder (‚ÄúTalking Book‚Äù) , The Monkeeys, etc. The twin forces of Wendy Carlos and Bob Moog were to move the synthesiser out of the workshop and into the recording studio and eventually it would go on the road.

Without Switched on Bach, maybe there would have been no Kraftwerk, no New Order, Yazoo. Nowadays the synth has taken its place alongside traditional instruments but have to wonder how many records are made today without synthetic music. Either way, it must be one of the seminal albums in music.

Footnote:
Anyone interested should take a look at the Wendy Carlos biography. It‚Äôs a fascinating read.
‚ÄúWendy Carlos‚Äù, by Amanda Sewell. ISBN 9780190053482

 

Oh I almost forgot, why don‚Äôt people hear this album? The answer is copyright.

You can get a copy from Amazon on CD. but you pay $32 US.

It has been blocked on streaming by Wendy Carlos for whatever reason. You can hear cover versions on Youtube since the works of JSB are long into the public domain, so if you can tell one from the other or it doesn‚Äôt matter, a sine wave is a sine wave, you can hear it there. But I have no doubt that it really did change music.
